revised_title: Trisomic Mutations in Wild Oenothera Species
tldr: The author studies trisomic mutations in a wild species of Oenothera, discovering that it produces a high percentage of trisomic mutations, even higher than Lamarckiana. The offspring of the dwarf plants were almost entirely trisomic, which is a unique occurrence. This wild species has survived in its natural habitat for 25 years, suggesting it should be recognized as a separate species.
